wikipedia_page.main: Sir Alfred William Wiggin  (24 February 1937 – 12 March 2015), known as Jerry Wiggin, was a British Conservative Party politician.

response: In May 1982, the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State (Jerry Wiggin) stated that the current replacement cost of a Type 42 destroyer of the Sheffield class was "about £120 million."Hansard HC Deb 27 May 1982 vol 24 c397W  Question to the Secretary of State for Defence about the current replacement cost of a Type 42 destroyer of the Sheffield class., 27 May 1982 In July 1984, the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State (John Lee) stated: "the average cost of the three Type 42 destroyers currently under construction is £117 million at 1983–84 price levels."Hansard HC Deb 23 July 1984 vol 64 c534W  Question to the Secretary of State for Defence about the latest cost estimate of aTtype 42 destroyer, 23 July 1984.

He unsuccessfully sought the conservative selection for Weston super-Mare in 1970, missing out to Jerry Wiggin.Clark, Alan Clark Diaries (2):In Power, p.271. He subsequently became MP for Plymouth Sutton at the February 1974 general election with a majority of 8,104,Trewin, p.245. when Harold Wilson took over from Edward Heath as prime minister of a minority Labour government. At the General Election in October 1974, when Labour gained a small overall majority, Clark's vote fell by 1,192 votes, but he still had a comfortable majority with 5,188.Trewin, p.250. His first five years in parliament were spent on the Conservative opposition benches. He was still a member of the Monday Club in May 1975.Copping, Robert, The Monday Club – Crisis and After, London, May 1975, p.25. It is unclear when he let his membership of the club lapse, but possibly it was upon becoming a government minister. He continued to address Club events until 1992.
Berry contested Weston-super-Mare at the 1983 General Election but was defeated by Jerry Wiggin. Berry also unsuccessfully fought the seat of Bristol for the European Parliament in 1984.

response: *Sir Jerry Wiggin (Alfred William Wiggin, 1937-2015), British Conservative Party politician

He was returned at three subsequent general elections, before his death in 1969, following injuries sustained in a skiing accident in Austria. He was 45 years old. The consequent by-election for his seat was won by the Conservative candidate, Jerry Wiggin.

The Conservative politician Sir Jerry Wiggin is the son of Colonel Sir William Henry Wiggin (1888–1951), son of Alfred Harold Wiggin, fourth son of the first Baronet. His son is the Conservative politician Bill Wiggin. Edgar Askin Wiggin (1867–1939), fifth son of the first Baronet, was a Brigadier-General in the Army.
|rowspan=2|Under-Secretary of State for Agriculture, Fisheries and Food||Jerry Wiggin||7 May 1979 – 29 September 1981||

The Conservative candidate was Alfred William (Jerry) Wiggin. Educated at Eton College and Trinity College, Cambridge, he was a farmer with holdings in Worcestershire and Peeblesshire.'Register: Sir Jerry Wiggin', Times, 10 April 2015. He had previously stood as the party's candidate in Montgomeryshire in 1964 and 1966.
**Sir Jerry Wiggin, 78, politician, MP for Weston-super-Mare (1969–1997).
*Sir Jerry Wiggin, 78, British politician, MP for Weston-super-Mare (1969–1997).WIGGIN

response: The Isle of Wight's MP Mark Woodnutt (Conservative) succeeded in passing a Private Member’s Bill – The Isle of Wight Act, 1971Royal ascent 05 August 1971 Hansard col. 1900-1 1900#23 – to control large scale gatherings in the Isle of Wight. Though not an outright ban, gatherings of more than 5,000 attending during the hours of 12.00 midnight and 6.00am were severely restricted. The Act effectively prevented further large scale festivals on the Island until the revival of the Isle of Wight Festival in 2002.To celebrate Her Majesty the Queen’s diamond jubilee the Isle of Wight Council invited private sector partner, Solo Agency, to co-promote a revival of the Isle of Wight Festival. An audience of 10,000 was accommodated at Seaclose Leisure Park, Newport. The following year Solo Agency took over the event and it has since run for 14 consecutive years increasing audience attendance to the present level of 60,000. Mark Woodnutt MP, Jerry Wiggin MP and seven other conservative members attempted to extend the Isle of Wight legislation to cover the whole of the United Kingdom with the ‘Night Assemblies Bill’.Clarke, Michael (1982) The Politics of Pop Festivals, London, Junction Books Ltd, p.63.  This was eventually shelved after the government appointed Denis StevensonNow Baron Stevenson of Coddenham, CBE, DL former chairman of HBOS. He sits on the crossbenches in the House of Lords to chair a committee to examine the issue. Partly due to evidence taken from Isle of Wight officials, notably Isle of Wight Rural District Council Medical Officer of Health, Dr Douglas Quantrill, and Chief Constable of Hampshire, (Sir) Douglas Osmond, Stephenson concluded that further legislation was unnecessary.Clarke, Michael (1982) The Politics of Pop Festivals London, Junction Books Ltd, pp.78-80.
